title: You can do the Show on a budget
text:
Rebecca Taylor, who plans to take her four sons to the show, said she liked to set realistic expectations for the boys before they arrived. 
“I pre-warn the children they can only get one showbag each,” she said. 
The family, from Seven Mile Beach, also sets a limit of two or three rides for the boys, who range in age from one to nine. 
“It’s mainly the older boys who like the rides, while the little ones just love the animals.” 
But they plan to spend up on show food. “It’s only once a year so we make a day of it and really enjoy it,” she said. Dodgem cars are the best value rides at the show because they fit two people. Picture: SCOTT FLETCHER Source: News Corp Australia 
Showmans’ Guild of Australia Tasmanian secretary Di Alexander said all rides were priced between $5 and $10. 
She said the best value were the dodgem cars, because an adult and child could ride for only $6 or $7. 
“They’re always the best value because you can fit two people in them,” she said. 
Showgoers can also get two-for-one-deals on the rides by collecting coupons in the Mercury newspaper. There will be two pages of coupons in Tuesday’s Mercury , all valid for the Saturday show. As well as rides, the coupons offer discounts on food and sideshow games. How to do the Show on a budget 
Entertainment 
Once showgoers have paid for entry, all entertainment is free. 
Highlights this year include: 
• The BMX Bandit — Scott Hone. The BMX stunt artist, who has travelled the world with Circus Oz, makes skids and wheelies look like ballet with a bike. 
• The Rooftop Express — Queensland cattlemen with highly trained horses and farm animals performing stunts on the ground and on the top of the Rooftop Express bus. 
• Zap Circus — an internationally acclaimed acrobatics and fire show, fresh from their tour of the US. Lots of fire, laughs and acrobatics. 
Rides 
All rides are priced between $5 and $10, with the little kids’ rides at $5. This year, for the first time in many years, a trad­itional carousel will be at the show, costing $6 a ticket. 
The teenage and adult rides cost between $8 and $10, with this year’s popular ones including the Alpine Express, Energy Storm, Lethal Weapon and the Hurricane. 
Dodgem cars will fit two people in a car for $6 or $7. Kurt Smith, 2, of Richmond, feeds the lambs and kids in the lead-up to the Hobart Show. Source: News Corp Australia 
Animals 
The animal nursery is among the most visited parts of the show, and definitely the cutest. There will be a variety of animals and their mothers, including sows and piglets, cows and calves, ducklings, chickens, guinea pigs, reptiles and a couple of baby Tasmanian devils. 
• Patting pen — hands-on section of the nursery where children can cuddle and pat the animals. 
• Reptile Rescue — an array of snakes and lizards. 
• Animal judging — nearly 700 dogs will vie for the Best Dog at the Show title. Other judging includes cats, sheep, poultry and cattle. 
Farm life • Beekeeping — an on-site beehive where people can learn about the role of the queen bee and see how honey is made. 
• Butter making — the trad­itional method before mach­ines were invented. 
• A Life on the Farm display will hold demonstrations of cow milking, sheep shearing and spud digging. 
• Pigs will be auctioned and raced. 
Brian Fish, of Oatlands, with his Bullock team. The agricultural side of the show is always popular. 
Showbags 
There are 151 different showbags this year. The most expensive showbags are $25, the medium priced bags are $10-15 and some are as cheap as three for $10. 
Among the cheapest bags are the confectionary ones, including the $6 Crunchie bag (containing $15.40 worth of treats) and the $6 Caramello Koala bag (valued at $16.05). 
The Cadbury Bumper Family Deal bag costs $20 and holds $41 worth of chocolate. 
The bag voted the best value by a group of Cosgrove High School students last week was the BFF bag. Priced at $25, the bag is said to contain $90 worth of merchandise including a duffel bag, purse, fabric paint, hair chalk, pencils, lipgloss, bracelet, jewellery box and small handbag. 
The Cosgrove students voted the Mega Combat bag as the best boys’ showbag, and the Frozen bag as the best girls’ showbag. 
Food 
The food can be as cheap or as expensive as budgets and tastebuds allow, ranging from sausages in bread up to gourmet fare in the food pavilion. 
The Royal Agricultural Soc­iety has two cafes and three bars at the show. 
Cheaper options include: $2 party pies and mini sausage rolls, $5.50 sandwiches, $6 rolls. 
Among the favourites, a bag of hot chips $5, pluto pup $5, potato cake/dim sim/seafood bite $1 each. 
In the gourmet category, the Oyster Bar will have oyster chowder $13, one dozen oysters (any style) $28 and deep-fried battered oysters $3 each. 
Entry prices 
All tickets are cheaper online than paying at the gate. 
A family ticket (two adults and two children) is $50 online and $58 at the gate. Additional children are $10 each. 
Adult entry is $20 online and $22 at the gate. 
Child entry is $13 online and $14 at the gate. 
The after-5pm family ticket is $37.50 online and $44 at the gate. Concession is $38 at the gate. 
More details at www.hobartshowground.com.au
